image.altText: Scott Rush, Matthew Norman, Si-Yi Chen, Martin Stephens standing in a line as legal documents are signed on a table in front

props.synopsis: The five remaining members of the Bali Nine have returned home to Australia, free to live their lives, after two decades in an Indonesian prison over a drug smuggling plot.

title.children: Remaining Bali Nine 'immensely grateful' for freedom in Australia

image.altText: HSBC signage

props.synopsis: The corporate watchdog is suing banking giant HSBC over a scam that netted $23 million, alleging it failed to protect 950 Australian customers.

title.children: ASIC to sue HSBC over 'spoofing' scam

image.altText: The Australian tourists were being monitored at Lautoka Hospital overnight and remain in critical condition this morning.

props.synopsis: A group of tourists are in critical condition in hospital in Fiji, as the Australian government warns against the risk of methanol poisoning.

title.children: 'Terrifying sense of deja vu': Four Australians in hospital in Fiji after suspected alcohol poisoning

image.altText: A group of half naked men sit on the ground beneath a ruined building.

props.synopsis: Jabalia, in the north of Gaza, has suffered some of the most intense bombardments by Israel since its war with Hamas began more than a year ago. Six residents have shared with the ABC their harrowing stories of one day.

title.children: A shocking image emerged from northern Gaza. We tracked down a man in it

image.altText: A woman with short brown hair and glasses stands behind a lectern with two small microphones.

props.synopsis: The treasurer will announce the members of the new-look Reserve Bank boards this morning, including two new members on the RBA's monetary board.

title.children: Two Reserve Bank monetary board members to be replaced under new-look RBA

image.altText: Ground staff run the covers onto the ground at the Gabba during a rain delay in the Test between Australia and India.

props.synopsis: Australia is in the box seat at the Gabba in Brisbane, where rain threatens to disrupt the third day of the third Test. Follow live.

title.children: Australia hopes for lower-order runs against India as rain returns on day three

image.altText: A female mine worker walks past a mine dump truck at a coal mine in central Queensland.

props.synopsis: Wednesday's update to the budget will reveal billions less in tax is expected from the mining sector, as the government sets expectations for a coming decade of budgets in deficit.

title.children: $100b blow to mining exports to knock billions out of government coffers

image.altText: The sun rises through boat masts over Port Phillip Bay.

props.synopsis: Victorians are being urged to brace for what is forecast to be the hottest day in years for parts of the state, as fire authorities warning of "horrendous" conditions and a high risk of bushfires.

title.children: 'Horrendous' fire danger risk in Victoria with Melbourne to hit 41C

image.altText: Doreen Langham's photo on a cracked phone with lights and sirens in the background.

props.synopsis: Doreen Langham was set alight by her ex-partner in 2021 in one of Queensland's most horrific domestic violence murders. Could a warning from inside police ranks have changed the outcome?

title.children: Cracks in police record-keeping flagged before Doreen Langham's death

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie looks into camera with a serious facial expression.

props.synopsis: Whether it's "Faux outrage" or online death threats, it's risky being a whistleblower and vested interests have a lot to answer for.

title.children: Doctors have received death threats for speaking out about colleagues

image.altText: Family members descend stairs outside a red brick building with green trees.

props.synopsis: Parents Georgina Burt and Andrew Dodt are the lead plaintiffs on a newly launched class action against the state of Tasmania and the operator of the Hillcrest jumping castle.

title.children: Families launch class action against Tasmania and jumping castle operator over Hillcrest tragedy

image.altText: A sign on the front of a building saying 'Genius Childcare', photographed through bars.

props.synopsis: Three Genius Childcare workers take legal action against the company over allegations it intentionally paid wages late and failed to pay them thousands of dollars in superannuation.

title.children: Workers sue Genius Childcare over alleged unpaid super, late wages

image.altText: Screenshot of a Moochies watch for sale online. The watch face shows a woman smiling with 'mum' as the contact being called.

props.synopsis: The company behind Moochies watches is in liquidation, but the devices are still being sold despite mounting complaints of SIM card issues, GPS errors and difficulties contacting the firm for refunds.

title.children: Telco ombudsman concerned 'unwitting parents' buying Moochies watches

image.altText: A man wearing a suit looks sideways as he speaks into a microphone

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the regime change in Syria is fuelling the need to bolster the Israeli population in the region.

title.children: Israel plans to double its population of settlers in the occupied Golan Heights

image.altText: Four magic mushrooms in an outstretched hand close-up.

props.synopsis: The discovery of a close relative of the world's most popular psychedelic fungus suggests magic mushrooms came from Africa about 1.5 million years ago.

title.children: Magic mushroom discovery might explain how species spread worldwide

image.altText: Two police officers walk on a road, in front of a fire amongst some trees on the roadside

props.synopsis: Seven people have died in a shocking 48-hour period on New South Wales roads.

title.children: Horror start to holiday season as seven people die on NSW roads

image.altText: Looking out to the valley from the level of the tracks over the bridge.

props.synopsis: Rail trail enthusiasts are one step closer to an exciting new nature experience, with plans underway for an extension of the scenic and historic Mary Valley track.

title.children: Rail trail extension hopes to attract 'wallets on wheels' to tiny towns

image.altText: Piles of corrugated and sheet metal surrounded by chunks of wood on the ground and stripped structures and trees

props.synopsis: The tropical storm is the worst to hit the French territory of Mayotte in the Indian Ocean in 90 years.

title.children: Cyclone hits Mayotte archipelago killing hundreds, possibly thousands

image.altText: Rob McEwan looks over with plans for construction laid out on a desk in an office.

props.synopsis: After workers dug up two skeletons at a Hobart school's hockey field it was believed there would likely be more, with the location being an old graveyard. But the scale of what the archaeological team found was staggering — and the job of putting names to the many bones was "like a giant puzzle".

title.children: Nearly 2,000 bodies were found under a school's sporting field, in what is believed to be Australia's biggest exhumation

image.altText: US troops carrying gunswalk towards a combat vehicle flying an American flag.

props.synopsis: The United States, Russia, Türkiye and Iran are among the key global players with a foothold in Syria. This is what they potentially stand to gain, or lose, from Assad's downfall.

title.children: The state of play for global powers in Syria after Assad's fall

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX 200 is priced to fall another 0.5% on top of last week's 1.5% decline. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to slide after Wall Street rally stalls

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Manufacturing production slips, but optimism picks up in latest PMI
Treasurer set to replace two members of new RBA monetary board
Budget to take a $8.5 billion hit over four years as mining tax streams dry up

image.altText: A young woman and an older man stand in a field.

props.synopsis: When journalist Danielle O'Neal revisited a sugar cane farm at the centre of a UFO media storm in the 1960s, she never could have predicted the scar tissue she would find.

title.children: Investigating a UFO mystery spanning 60 years

image.altText: Steve Smith waves his bat aggressively in celebration of a century

props.synopsis: Steve Smith has been trying everything to rediscover his form, and in the end it took a return to the method that launched his career to bring about his breakthrough Gabba ton.

title.children: The tiny tweak that allowed Steve Smith to rediscover himself

image.altText: Rectangular bales of plastic recyclables stacked on top of each other.

props.synopsis: Billionaire and climate activist Annie Cannon-Brookes joins a growing opposition to a proposed plastic recycling project in the NSW Southern Highlands.

title.children: Billionaire Annie Cannon-Brookes opposes planned NSW plastic recycling plant

image.altText: Children play in Ngukurr's public pool

props.synopsis: For those living in northern Australia, local pools are a part of everyday life. But for remote councils, the costs of keeping a pool up and running can be crippling, leaving some communities without a safe place to swim.

title.children: Calls for safe place to swim as community fears fatal croc attack

image.altText: A single bed in a room at the new youth training centre

props.synopsis: Nearly one in two incarcerated children in South Australia have been prescribed a supplement to help them fall asleep, amid concerns about "unusual" night-time behaviours.

title.children: Doctors concerned by melatonin prescriptions to children at detention centre

image.altText: Blurred Graffiti under bridge in Sefton

props.synopsis: NSW Police are investigating the "offensive graffiti" that appeared under a bridge in Sefton after receiving reports about 9:40am on Sunday.

title.children: Islamophobic graffiti in Sydney's west condemned as 'disgusting', 'gutless'

image.altText: A woman with tattoos and piercings holds her young people

props.synopsis: With forecasts suggesting extreme heat will become more common across Sydney's west, alarms over whether its already burn-out healthcare system can cope are growing.

title.children: Alarms raised for healthcare access as heat climbs across Sydney’s west

image.altText: A carved emu egg featuring a dragon backlit by a blue light.

props.synopsis: Stavros Margaritis has been carving emu eggs for decades and displaying them in his gun-shop-turned art gallery in St George. Now his daughter is embracing the family art.

title.children: Passion for intricate emu egg carving shines through another generation

image.altText: A red and blue oil tanker split in two with the vessel's bow pointing vertically up out of dark sea water

props.synopsis: Russia has opened two criminal investigations into potential safety violations after at least one person died and another tanker was significantly damaged in the weather.

title.children: Russian oil tanker split in half and sinks in storm in the Black Sea

image.altText: Former deputy premier Troy Grant, former siege hostage Louisa Hope and former police officer Ben Besant together cafe behind

props.synopsis: It is 10 years today since a lone-wolf gunman walked into the Lindt Cafe and took 18 people hostage, demanding politicians declare Australia was under attack from Islamic State.

title.children: Lindt Cafe siege remembered 10 years after terrifying images beamed around the world

image.altText: Hilton Cartwright taken from field in a neck brace after suffering an injury during a BBL match.

props.synopsis: Hilton Cartwright is released from hospital after being stretchered off the ground during the Melbourne Stars' loss to the Scorchers in Perth.

title.children: Stars all-rounder Cartwright cleared of serious neck injury after fielding mishap in BBL opener

image.altText: A burning boat.

props.synopsis: More than 2,000 illegal foreign fishing boats have been picked up in Australian waters over the past decade, but the boats keep coming.

title.children: Why are so many illegal fishing vessels targeting Australia's northern coast?

image.altText: Nicola, right, looks longingly at Luke, left, who lightly touches her face while outside in the evening.

props.synopsis: Whether it was in enormous blockbusters, anarchic music films or swoony romance, our big screens have been dominated by Irish actors this year. And a deeply embedded cultural respect for the arts could be part of their success.

title.children: From Paul Mescal to Nicola Coughlan, Irish actors are taking over Hollywood
